There were so many deliberate shots of famous people and of Sony logos and electronic devices, along with Cadillac automobiles, 5-star restaurants, lavish cruise lines and background scenery we missed the point of the story.Too bad, because twins are a special thing even if they are CGI, this movie absolutely missed that mark entirely.

Let me start by saying that Allen Covert as a "Homless Guy" is probably the best part of this film. Now this movie right from the get go, seemed to have potential and this later shines through in some great laughs along the way, though two big problems rear their ugly heads early on.The first being that Adam Sandler is not really the most attractive man in the world and it seems like the makeup department failed to realizes this, because they put forward no effort to make him actually look like a woman. There is a point in the movie where you actually get to see how much work he goes through in his gender change, lets just say I'm not impressed. The other actors that play opposite genders in there movie tend to do it about a 100X more convincingly, when I see Madea I don't think "Hey that's just Tyler Perry in drag" I look at Madea and see a hilarious black woman, that if nobody had told me was a man I would have never figured out on my own. This is not the case with Jill, who you think of as a woman, but every time you see her breaks this illusion by simply being Adam Sandler in a wig.The second big problem with this movie is Katie Holmes, whether you love her or you hate her it just seems glaringly obvious that she didn't belong in this movie. I've never looked at Katie Holmes as a comedy actress and that is probably because she has never made me laugh and after watching this movie that record has continued. I don't think she's a bad actress by any means, but there were probably about a thousand better options for the role. She doesn't play off of Sandler very well and they really just seem like 2 people pretending to be married, this is probably the weakest paring that Sandler has ever been a part of on the big screen. By the time this movie ends if have anything at all to say about Katie Holmes character, I highly doubt it anything good. All-in-all my opinion is that this movie probably shouldn't have been made in the first place, the weak pointless storyline, the shallow and mildly upsetting characters, and the fact that the estimated budget for this ridicules film was almost $80 million, all add up to disaster in my book, a disaster that you should probably avoid.

Don't believe the critics, see it for yourself and decide. Despite being warned I went to see this movie. Very typical Sandler Humor along the lines of Dumb and Dumber, but a little higher on the scatological scale. Not belly laughs, very predictable, clever at best, slapstick at worst. Most bits are funny.What takes this to the next level is the performance of Al Pacino. The ongoing gag works and although a little redundant, it is over the top enough to make the movie worthwhile. While it is certainly not in the same league as Animal House, Superbad, or Monty Python, it does not deserve the universal bashing it has received.

Review title: I would rather sit in a darkened room that was also a sewage outlet
Review_body: I find it hard to put into words just how poor this film really is. All I can say, without any fear of 'spoiling' the film is that: a) Adam Sandler is as convincing a woman as one of Goldilocks' three bears. Or perhaps the wolf from Red Riding Hood. b) I doubt that either Al Pacino OR Katie Holmes ever saw the final edit of this prior to release or they may have politely asked the makers to remove all evidence of them from it. c) For $79m, I would happily have filmed the inhabitants of my local bar for one week and got more story, laughs and character development and much fewer fart jokes and casual racism. d) If anyone ever suggests that I watch the film again, I will consult a solicitor BEFORE I set about them with some golf clubs. PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE don't watch this film. It is 91 minutes of your life that you will never get back...

Review title: Takes a moment to get used to, then pleasantly surprising! (just like having twins!)
Review_body: As a mom of TWO sets of twins – (One set 13. One set 30. Child bride. No kidding. Dad didn't have to bring a shotgun. Didn't need it. Mom was a rifle type of gal.) – That being neither here nor there: this movie goer' was actually very impressed with Jack and Jill.My husband and I took our 13 year old twin sons, who laughed the entire show. It does take a few moments to forget that Jill is actually Adam Sandler, but all of us agreed that we soon saw Jack and Jill as two different characters, and as twins. Grown twins do fight and no one knows better which buttons to push. When my grown boys disagree (as they often do) the rest of us just stay out of the way.I'm beginning to wonder if some of the online reviewers didn't see a different movie than we? And different not only than we -but different than the others in the theater with us. EVERYONE was laughing. Some hysterically.We went expecting a zany, light hearted comedy. We actually came away with more than that. Not only was the interaction of the twins hilarious, but interjected moments of the unique sense of loss that Jill felt, as the caretaker of their mother, were very insightful. I lost my own mother two years ago. We had our own special holiday traditions, and life has been very different without her. There was more to this little movie than first meets the eye, and our family was very pleased.Every actor, down to the smallest child with the lobster taped to his back, was absolutely wonderful! Al Pacino as Al Pacino was genius! Katie Holmes and the dish of chocolate ice-cream! That was not only funny, it was just right! Not too much, not too little. Every move she made in the entire movie was totally believable. And guess what? I'm not a huge Katie Holmes OR even an Adam Sandler fan; however he was quite a bit of a genius himself, keeping in character for TWO characters! (And NO, I'm not the mother of any of these people. Trust me, out of SIX kids, only one's in California. And he is not an actor. Can't tell you what he does, or he'd have to kill you ;-)Just see the movie. Decide for yourself. Take twins of any age. It's safe. (Ok, so one Mexican American does look under Jill's skirt, but who can blame him for wondering what was going on down south of that?)

Review title: One scene makes movie worth a 5.0
Review_body: Overall this movie is not very good. It's somewhat painful to watch, but nowhere near the worst movie ever. It is, however, light-years from the best film ever. Yet, there is one scene that makes this movie worth watching (up until that scene, at least). In the movie the son of Jack keeps scotch-taping items to himself. Even this semi-humorous aspect of the film wears out fairly quickly, BUT, BUT, BUT, before the humor is gone there is the scene with the mythical beast, the "Peppercorn."The Peppercorn is easily a painful belly laugh--an intense focal point of funny that makes me give the film a five-star rating even if every other scene in the film warrants a zero. (And it just about does,...)Sure we should expect low-brow from Sandler, but do we have to settle for encephalitis? Come on, Adam, you can do way better.Rent this movie for a dollar from Redbox, watch the first fifteen minutes until the Peppercorn scene, laugh really hard, and then turn the film off. Thank me later.

Review title: Small laughs littered abundantly but an overall forgettable popcorn flick.
Review_body: Jack & Jill, while slapshtick - literally, shtick - it still offered enough genuine laughs to be a funny, of the genre flick. It appears that Happy Madison, namely Adam Sandler really knows his comedy. If you're not a fan of his Mr. Deeds and his antics then you likely won't enjoy Sandler playing both titular roles, both male and female identical twins; but if you could manage to sit through 50 First Dates then you'll be in for a treat; Sandler reuses about 50 of his previous jokes to above average results. Overall, Jack & Jill is a solid big budget comedy headed up by a talented production team featuring a slew of winning cameos that you won't have to look hard to spot. Rent it, don't buy it. 5/10

Review_body: I have no idea what is wrong with everyone reviewing this movie - get a sense of humor!This movie makes me laugh from start to finish. I love Jill, Katie Holmes is so charming, the little son is hysterical! There's plenty of zaniness and physical stunts - and lots of fart jokes! Hysterical!As a feminist, I am so appreciative of this film. Jill is a huge woman with a huger personality and the men love her! Do you have any idea how rare it is to see that in film? It makes me so happy that this "disaster" of a woman is such an incredible person. The story plays on gender stereotypes in the best of ways. I want to see more Jills in the world! Review title: Sandler's never been one for artistically brilliant movies, why would we expect this one to be any different?
Review_body: Adam Sandler is known for creating generic, box office garbage. Something to watch when there's nothing else on or something to put on in the background whilst you scroll through your laptop. His movies have always been light gags and ridiculous humour. Which is exactly why I don't understand how this one was attacked so much. Remember Bedtime stories? Or what about Little Nicky? They were much worse and yet Bedtime stories got more credit.The point is that Sandler's movies are all the same and why should we expect any different? It's his style, as cancerous as it is to watch, he's made some good money off of it.Now I'm not saying I like this movie but I think he's done worse. Al Paccino was in it. How in the world did he even get Al Paccino to be in it? Anyway, the gags are stupid, the jokes are stupid, the movie's stupid but it had it's moments that made me smile.

Jack and Jill tells the story of Jack's sister, Jill, coming to visit his family for Thanksgiving. She's only supposed to be there for a few days, but she extends her vacation time, and winds up staying almost to New Years. During her stay you are going to see a lot of bad from a lot of great actors. This film is one of the worst films Adam Sandler has ever done. The only thing that does makes it funny is its stupidity, and the fact that Adam Sandler is playing a woman. However, Adam does not make a very pretty woman. It seems like each new movie Adam is in gets worse ans worse. He used to make great films like Happy Gilmore and Big Daddy. Great films are supposed to keep you laughing the entire time, and have a great story behind it. Sadly, this film has neither. This film also has Al Pacino in it. In my opinion, he makes a complete fool of himself. Adam Sandler puts him in a commercial at the end of the film where he sings a terrible Dunkin Donuts song. Pacino is mostly recognized as a feared man in his films. I honestly can't believe he agreed to this film. Although everything I have stated above is bad, I am still a huge Adam Sandler fan. He is the only reason I wanted to see the film. It's certainly not the worst film of the century, but it is pretty annoying. If you are a huge fan like myself, I would recommend this to a friend. My review is just an opinion, and I am sure there are people out there that loved this film. Unfortunately, I am not one of those people. There are a few funny parts in the film, but it is mostly just bad acting. The jokes in the film aren't jokes that would make adults laugh. Let's just say if there is a showing for Jack and Jill 2, I won't be watching it.

Finally a comedy that didn't offend me with bad language, or crude/stupid humor. I like Adam Sandler as a comedian and the cast from SNL but I haven't enjoy many of their movies because of bad language or offensive humor. However, this one, is absolutely an enjoyable comedy. Adam Sandler gained many points in my books with this movie. Clean, safe for the whole family, and pure humor. I watched it alone and it's hard for me to laugh or be excited when I am alone and yet I laughed loud and was very into the movie. Thumbs up.

For an actor, screenwriter and producer with over 30 movies under his belt, you'd think Adam Sandler would've learned you can only disappoint an audience so many times, and there comes a point where effort actually has to be put into the movie for it to succeed.This is what I would've said if this movie had failed. But it actually made money. People went to see a movie where Adam Sandler played in drag for 90 minutes.The fact we as an audience keep giving this man money to make more movies, when other truly great actors and writers struggle to get the attention they deserve is insulting.Let me explain why this movie is so awful. Adam Sandler graduated from making movies that don't really work and aren't interesting to a movie that punishes the audience for seeing it.This movie begins with at least 3 product placements. Dunkin Donuts and Pepto-Bismol, both of which are somewhat important to the "plot" and then an incredibly obvious Coke advertisement. Great first impression for your audience which you clearly treat as intelligent consumers.Stuff kind of just happens in this movie, like most of Adam Sandler's movies. All the characters are boring except for Jack and Jill mainly because they cause an actually feeling for the viewer.Pain. This movie manages to make you dislike both of the main characters in a set-up where that should be virtually impossible. Jack is a total jerk to his sister and doesn't handle the situation well by not telling her how he feels in an adult manner. The reasoning for this is probably supposed to be that she is messing with his career, although there isn't one scene that shows this. A main character who has his name in the movie title being unlikable would be bad enough in any normal film, but for this one, that isn't even a primary concern.I'm sure they'll make up for this. I'm sure Jill is the one you understand and empathize with despite her obnoxiousness.Nope.Jill is incredibly annoying and the viewer is given no explanation as to why she is this way. For all I know Jill could be a sadist and is pretending to be stupid in order to annoy everyone she knows.The jokes are also even less funny than most Adam Sandler comedies. There was only one joke I smiled at in this whole film, and of course this was ironically. This was Al Pacino's utterly pointless disguise during the basketball game. Oh did I mention he was in this movie? I think he win's the award for farthest fall from grace. He is identified during the game, which is unintentionally funny because he literally has a first row seat and is sitting next to Johnny Depp, who has even less of a reason to be in this film.Speaking of unfunny jokes there is of course an insultingly racist character and scene in this film. There's a Mexican guy who is of course Jack's gardener. He bring's Jill to his family's party, in a scene which is difficult to describe due to awfulness.Here's a one sentence summary: He tells Jill not to eat the hot peppers and Jill plays soccer and keeps knocking over an old lady who doesn't like her for some reason with the ball and they revive her with the hot peppers and they keep feeding her the peppers ha ha get it guys because she's Mexican and she can eats the hot peppers but white people can't do you get it guys i don't think you get it why aren't you laughingAt this point I would not be surprised if half the people left the theater. But Adam Sandler knew that if one single person had a shred of investment in this film he hadn't done his job right.If you thought it couldn't get any worse, I'm afraid you haven't seen the last 3rd of the movie. In a stupid series of events that are honestly not worth your time because they make no sense Jack has to pretend to be Jill in order to make Al Pacino do an ad for him. Don't ask. So let me explain this.In the movie, Adam Sandler's character Jack, has to dress up in drag as Jill, a character Adam Sandler plays in drag. It's like the inception of stupidity. This is an example of breaking the fourth wall which I'm sure you would be instructed not to do in any starter level screen writing class. This is effectively the same as the movie stopping in the middle to show you a behind the scenes of the movie you are watching. It completely removes any investment in the film.Breaking the fourth wall only works in movies you are not supposed to take seriously or are supposed to break the fourth wall. This includes:Parodies (Ones that are actually funny i.e. Monty Python, Mel brooks, airplane, austin powers, etc) DeadpoolYou could say this movie fits into the not to take seriously category, but the reason it doesn't work much like most parodies is this requires that the movie is actually funny and lovable.
If you want mindless stupid fun, this is it. Watching Al Pachino doing a song and dance routine to a Dunkin Doughnuts commercial is worth watching.

This movie is pretty decent, and I enjoyed it a lot. I really don't understand the consistently negative reviews. You know what to expect with Adam Sandler, so there's no point pretending.But this film actually made me laugh a lot, and I also empathised with the characters. The chemistry between the actors, the energy of the film, and the story flow were all excellent. The plot does not hold any surprises, but I don't hold that against it -- it's a classic movie plot.There are some really cheesy and cringe-worthy moments that I remember with a smile on my face. Think about it: There must be something to this movie that inspires such strength of feeling in so many reviewers... And it's not that it's "so bad it's good" -- it actually is good! I think some reviewers are in denial, feeling ashamed of themselves for secretly enjoying the cheesy humour.It's actually better than some of his other movies, for example the acting in "Just Go With It" was much more stilted and awkward.Jack and Jill is definitely worth a watch, if you enjoy Adam Sandler's humour.
